A subset is a set where all of its elements are also contained within another set.
Galois Group of a Finite Field Extension

The Galois group, or automorphism group, $\\[\operatorname{Aut}_{\mathbb{F}_q}(\mathbb{F}_{q'})\]$ of a finite field extension $\\[\mathbb{F}_{q'} / \mathbb{F}_q\]$ is the group of field automorphisms of $\\[\mathbb{F}_{q'}\]$ that fix $\\[\mathbb{F}_q\]$. It is cyclic of order $n$, where $n$ is the degree of the extension.
Does the concept of a/an Subset need to be defined for a definition of a/an Galois Group of a Finite Field Extension to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: To understand the definition of the Galois group of a finite field extension, we need to comprehend the concept of field automorphisms that fix a certain field, specifically $\mathbb{F}_q$ in this case. The definition states that the Galois group consists of automorphisms of $\mathbb{F}_{q'}$ that fix every element of $\mathbb{F}_q$. This implies that $\mathbb{F}_q$ must be a subset of $\mathbb{F}_{q'}$ for the automorphisms to have elements to fix. Therefore, understanding what it means for one set (or field, in this context) to be a subset of another is crucial to understanding the definition of the Galois group. Without the concept of a subset, the notion of fixing $\mathbb{F}_q$ within $\mathbb{F}_{q'}$ would not be meaningful, as it inherently relies on the idea that all elements of $\mathbb{F}_q$ are contained within $\mathbb{F}_{q'}$. Thus, the concept of a subset is necessary for the definition of the Galois group of a finite field extension to make sense.
